subject: Art & Design
title: Anchoring Bias: The First Number Wins
description: A 60-second lesson on Anchoring Bias: The First Number Wins.

hook.text: A jacket 'was' $200, now $99. The $200 makes $99 feel like a steal. But what if it was always worth $99?

buildup.text: Anchoring bias: the first piece of information (the anchor) disproportionately influences subsequent judgments.

discovery.text: Pricing pages show the expensive plan first. The mid-tier suddenly looks reasonable by comparison.

climax.text: Apple announces iPhone at $999. Then shows the 'affordable' model at $699. $699 feels cheap ‚Äî because of the anchor.

punchline.text: You don't evaluate prices in a vacuum.

quiz.question: How does anchoring bias affect pricing perception?
options: The first price seen becomes a reference point that makes later prices seem cheaper
People always choose the cheapest option
Higher prices make people leave the page
